Executive Summary

Chevron Phillips Chemical Puerto Rico Core Inc.

5 Year Risk Management Plan Revision





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



Chevron Phillips Chemical Puerto Rico Core Inc. (CPCPRC) is committed to protecting the health and safety of its employees, the public and the environment.  CPCPRC takes seriously the obligation to provide information to the community, as well as to actively participate in community emergency planning and community right-to-know.  This includes public access to information on chemicals manufactured, handled and stored within the facility.  

    CPCPRC's policy is to implement controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances through engineering design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes in the facility.  However, if a release does occur, CPCPRC trained employees shall respond to control and contain the release.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED



CPCPRC is a petrochemical plant located on the southeast coast of the island of Puerto Rico.  The facility is situated approximately 2.5 miles southwest of the town of Guayama, in Jobos  Ward, adyacent to State Road Number 710 and approximately 0.25 miles from the Caribbean Sea.

The operating facilities include a series of petrochemical units designed to produce a select, high purity group of aromatic hydrocarbons.  Motor fuel gasoline and diesel, belonging to CITGO is stored in several of the facility's tanks and sold and distributed through the Truck Loading Terminal located at the facility.

Feedstock

Mixed-xylenes - 7,500 bbls per day 



Products

Paraxylene - 6,000 bbls per day 

Benzene    -    700 bbls per day



General Process Flow

a) Mixed Xylenes are charged to the Parex Unit where paraxylene is adsorbed on mol sieves 

and then desorbed to produce high purity paraxylene. The other C8 Aromatics (raffinate) are then charged to an Isomerization Unit where orthoxylene and

metaxylene are converted to paraxylene and ethylbenzene is dealkylated to benzene. This dealkylation requires hydrogen that is produced in a steam reformer using gas from the isomerization unit as feed or butane as startup feed.



All feedstocks and most product shipments are via tankers through the marine dock facility located on the south coast of the region, specifically Las Mareas Harbor.  All of the gasoline and diesel is loaded via tank trucks at the truck loading rack for use on the island.  Excess hydrogen produced during our process is also sold via tank trucks for use in Puerto Rico.

Paraxylene and Benzene produced at CPCPRC serve as building blocks for many chemicals produced by our customers.  Paraxylene is used as a feedstock for producing polyester (poly/ cotton blend fabrics) and PET resins (soft drink bottles, X-ray film such as Mylar).  Benzene is used to make cyclohexane, which is used to produce nylon; and styrene, an intermediate for plastics. 

In these processes, CPCPRC has identified one flammable product that exceeds the threshold levels established by the List Rule of the Clean Water Act.  The flammable identified is butane.  The butane is stored in 2 spheres, each containing 1,891,512 pounds.  



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS (WCS & ARS)



Worst Case Release Scenarios (WCS) and Alternate Release Scenarios (ARS) were developed for the flammable identified in the facility using the EPA's RMP Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities.  The covered process was examined for the determination of the Flammable WCS and ARS for the facility.   Populations affected were based on census data.

The Flammables WCS was determined by modeling each of the two sphere in EPA's RMP Guidance.  Again, for the Flammables WCS, no secondary containment was considered and the vessel contents were modeled as an instantaneous release of the total contents of the vessel.  

The Flammable WCS selected was determined to be a Butane sphere releasing all 1,900,000 pound

s instantaneously and creating a Vapor Cloud Explosion.  The distance to the endpoint was determined to be 1.0 miles and affecting a population of 1,700 people.  The Flammable ARS was also calculated using EPA's RMP Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities The scenario modelled was also a Vapor Cloud Explosion resulting from a release of 47,000 pounds, with a release distance to the endpoint of 0.20 miles and affecting a population of 150 people.  The modeling was done using a 3 inch release for 30 minutes from the bottom of one of the butane spheres.  



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PROGRAM



    CPCPRC utilizes several Environmental, Health and Safety policies to identify improvement opportunities in the areas of employee involvement, productivity, quality and loss prevention.  Through the use of Responsible Care, the Tenets of Operations, Corporate EHS policy and the plant's own EHS policy, CPCPRC identifies areas in which people, systems and assets can be managed to maximize operating reliability and reduce the potential for releases in the facility.  Following are some of the areas in which the general accident release program is supported by the _______________________________________.                           .

Employee Participation

    CPCPRC encourages employees from all levels to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention in the facility.  Examples of employee participation range from active participation in developing, reviewing and revising safety standards, up to participating as members of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  In addition, CPCPRC supports employees by providing roles and responsibilities, training in safety and loss prevention, encouraging employee involvement through key performance measures and participation in a Citizens Advisory Panel )CAP) in which risks and rewards of the local chemical industry are discussed.

Systems

    CPCPRC uses systems to enhance the release prevention program in specific ways.  Th

rough process hazard analysis (PHAs), regulatory compliance and corporate audits, incident investigations, standards and procedures, and evaluation of contractor performance, CPCPRC works to reduce the probability that a release will occur.

Assets

    CPCPRC uses engineering design and mechanical reliability elements to minimize release potential and to ensure potential releases are controlled at the source.  This includes the evaluation of system designs and areas for improvement.  In addition, CPCPRC ensures all employees understand the impact of their actions on pollution.  CPCPRC also uses risk management to lessen identified risks to acceptable levels through the use of a risk identification, assessment and management system.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

    CPCPRC (and/or Phillips Puerto Rico Core Inc.) has an excellent record of accident prevention over the last five years.  No incidents resulted in off-site impacts.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

    CPCPRC maintains a comprehensive emergency response plan to prepare for and manage all emergencies affecting the facility or the community.  The plan includes: the Emergency Action Plan, Incident Command System - Management, Incident Command System - Unit Leader Guidelines, Emergency Response Team Manual, Emergency Equipment Inventory, Emergency Response Standard Operating Guidelines, Fire Preplans, Mutual Aid, Emergency Equipment Operating and Training Manual, Facility Response Plan, Training Lesson Plans, Fire Pump Maintenance and Inspection, and Storage Tank Fire Preplans.

    Employees in the facility are organized into the Initial Response Team, Fire Brigade, Specialty Teams and Incident Command System.  The Initial Response Team, which consists of operators for 24-hour coverage, acts as first responders to releases and other incidents.  The Fire Brigade consists of employees from all levels throughout the facility manage all incidents beyond the incipient stage.  Members of both the Initial Response Teams

and the Volunteer Fire Brigade are assigned to specialty teams for additional response capabilities.  These specialty teams include the Hazardous Materials Team, the Rescue Team, the Equipment Operators Team, and the Emergency Medical Service Team.  The Incident Command System also provides a structure for management personnel to support the field response organization and involves office personnel from the plant manager down.  Emergency response personnel receive approximately 32 hours per year of specialized training in addition to on the job training and drills.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

    CPCPRC intends to use the ________________ Plan to enhance employee involvement, facility productivity, quality, and loss prevention.  In addition to the goals outlined by the __________ Plan for the facility's people, systems and assets, CPCPRC will respond to PHA requirements, corporate regulatory audits and incident investigation findings and shall continue to strive to be considered a valued partner in our community.
